docs.abstract: The documentary “Civil” follows Ben Crump, the prominent attorney who has represented families affected by police violence, for one turbulent year.
docs.snippet: The documentary “Civil” follows Ben Crump, the prominent attorney who has represented families affected by police violence, for one turbulent year.
docs.lead_paragraph: At the beginning of “Civil” — a documentary about the civil-rights attorney Ben Crump — a phone call from Tera Brown, a cousin of George Floyd, comes into Crump’s office. Crump listens compassionately as Brown relates the 2020 murder of her cousin by a Minneapolis police officer. Crump gently offers her some advice about next steps, then rests his head in his hands. The image of Crump holding his own head, and of Crump rubbing his eyes, is repeated throughout “Civil.” It is the weary physical response to ongoing injustice and to a schedule that keeps the lawyer on planes and on his smartphone, pursuing lawsuits intended to make police departments and municipalities pay financially — and the media and the court of public opinion pay heed.

headline.main: ‘Civil: Ben Crump’ Review: What Becomes of a Missed Opportunity?

docs.abstract: Bishop Robert J. McManus of the Diocese of Worcester, Mass., said flying the flags contradicts “Catholic social and moral teaching.” The school has refused to take them down.
docs.snippet: Bishop Robert J. McManus of the Diocese of Worcester, Mass., said flying the flags contradicts “Catholic social and moral teaching.” The school has refused to take them down.
docs.lead_paragraph: The students at a predominantly Black Catholic middle school in Worcester, Mass., had resoundingly expressed their wishes in January 2021: They wanted Black Lives Matter and Pride flags flown over their place of learning to signal inclusivity.

headline.main: School’s Catholic Title in Peril Over Pride and Black Lives Matter Flags

docs.abstract: For nearly the entirety of Donald J. Trump’s four years in the White House, the Proud Boys protested — and often brawled — on the streets as part of a never-ending series of culture-war skirmishes. They opposed the removal of Confederate-era statues, the supposed spread of Shariah law and the mass demonstrations that emerged in response to the murder of George Floyd in Minneapolis.
docs.lead_paragraph: For nearly the entirety of Donald J. Trump’s four years in the White House, the Proud Boys protested — and often brawled — on the streets as part of a never-ending series of culture-war skirmishes. They opposed the removal of Confederate-era statues, the supposed spread of Shariah law and the mass demonstrations that emerged in response to the murder of George Floyd in Minneapolis.

headline.main: The Proud Boys, who were at the center of the Capitol riot, have a history of street fighting.
headline.print_headline: At Riot’s Center, The Proud Boys

docs.abstract: Public sentiment toward the monarchy has soured in the region, and calls for reparations for Britain’s often brutal role in the slave trade have been rising.
docs.snippet: Public sentiment toward the monarchy has soured in the region, and calls for reparations for Britain’s often brutal role in the slave trade have been rising.
docs.lead_paragraph: Of all the places where Queen Elizabeth II remains head of state, the future of the monarchy looks bleakest among the nations of the Caribbean.

headline.main: In the wake of Black Lives Matter, the Caribbean reassesses the British crown.

keywords.name: persons
keywords.value: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

docs.abstract: There’s now a more conservative alternative to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce.
docs.snippet: There’s now a more conservative alternative to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce.
docs.lead_paragraph: Big Business and the Republican Party used to be as close as Tweedledum and Tweedledee, but not anymore. On social issues such as abortion and race, the Republican Party has moved to the right while many big corporations have shifted left in an effort to please their diverse mix of employees and customers. Many companies embraced Black Lives Matter. Now a number are promising to cover travel expenses for employees who need to go to another state to get an abortion.

headline.main: As Big Business Is Accused of Becoming ‘Woke,’ Small Business Is Looking to Go Its Own Way
